contents.title: About Content v2
contents.description: Back home

children.value: About Content v2
Back home

The legislator wants data subjects to be provided with clear information about what data processing is carried out in the course of using a service. Among other things, data subjects should be provided with information about the type of data processed, the recipients of the data, and the purposes for which the data is processed.
The following information about data being processed should be provided to the data-subjects:
The
purpose
of processing
Receivers
of data
Transmission to
Non-EU
countries
The
legal basis
for the processing
The
legitimate interests
pursued by the controller or by a third party
The period for which the personal data will be
stored
Current solutions for providing information about data processing are mostly based on
textual privacy policies

.
Since these documents are usually of a global nature, i.e. they contain information about all data processing operations that occur in the service, they are often
long and complex
. In addition, information is usually provided in the form of
categories
of processed data or categories of recipients, since the specific data and recipients may depend on the user's interaction with the service.
Some processings require the
consent of the data subjects
. In this context, the legislator wants to ensure that sufficient information about the planned data processing is provided to data subjects so that they can make an
informed decision

The legislator provides for two types of information to be provided to data subjects:
Information about the intended processing such as:
Data
or categories of data
Recipients
or categories of recipients
Purposes
of the processing
Duration of the
storage
of data
In addition, data subjects should be informed of their
data subject rights
at the moment of consent. This includes, for example:
The right to
withdraw
consent
The right to
information
about the data being processed
The right to have the data
deleted
Currently used forms of consent provide the required information in
textual
form, usually as a privacy policy. These are also usually managed as a
separate
resource that must be explicitly accessed.
This is the context of
process

children.name: Contact details of the controller
children.description: The data controller must provide the data subject with contact information about themselves and a point of contact.

children.name: Clarification about processing
children.description: The controller must sufficiently inform data subjects about all data processing carried out.

children.name: Disclosure of purposes
children.description: The controller must sufficiently inform data subjects about the purposes of data processing.

children.name: Change of purpose
children.description: If the purpose of processing changes, the controller must inform the data subject about the new purposes.

children.name: Transmission of data
children.description: If data is transferred to another institution, the data controller must notify the data subject.

children.name: Third countries
children.description: If data is transferred to third countries, the controller must disclose to which third countries and on what legal basis.

children.name: Data protection officer
children.description: The controller must inform the data subjects of its data protection officer.

children.name: Lodge a complaint
children.description: The data controller must inform the data subjects about the possibility of the right of lodging a complaint.

children.name: Legal basis
children.description: The controller must inform the data subjects about the legal basis of the processing.

children.name: Legitimate interests
children.description: If the data processing is based on legitimate interests, the controller must communicate its interests to the data subjects

children.name: Automated decision-making
children.description: If a decision by the controller is based entirely on automated data processing, the controller must inform the data subject of this.

children.name: Clarification about subject rights
children.description: The data controller must inform the data subjects of the data subject rights they are entitled to.

body.name: Consent
body.description: Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

children.name: Informed consent
children.description: The controller must sufficiently inform the data subject about all essential points of the processing.

children.name: Withdraw
children.description: Data subjects may revoke their consent to data processing at any time.

body.name: Rights of the data subject
body.description: Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

children.name: Right of access
children.description: If data of a data subject is processed, the controller must provide the data subjects with information about this.

children.name: Right to rectification
children.description: If data of a data subject is inaccurate or incomplete, the data controller must correct or complete it.

children.name: Right to erasure
children.description: If there is a reason for deletion from Art. 17 GDPR, the controller must delete the corresponding data of the data subject.

children.name: Right to restriction
children.description: If one of the conditions from Art. 18 (1) a - d DSGVO is met, the controller must restrict processing in various situations.

children.name: Right to object
children.description: Data subjects have the right to object to the processing of their data.

children.name: Right to data portability
children.description: The data controller must provide the data subject or another data controller with data in a common and structured machine-readable format.

contents.title: Art7
contents.description: Where processing is based on consent, the controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consented to processing of his or her personal data.
contents.content: The data subject shall have the right to withdraw his or her consent at any time.

contents.title: Art12
contents.description: The controller shall take appropriate measures to provide any information referred to in Articles 13 and 14 and any communication under Articles 15 to 22 and 34 relating to processing to the data subject in a concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language, in particular for any information addressed specifically to a child. 2The information shall be provided in writing, or by other means, including, where appropriate, by electronic means. 3When requested by the data subject, the information may be provided orally, provided that the identity of the data subject is proven by other means
contents.content: Information in easily accessible form; Facilitate the exercice of data subject rights

contents.title: Art13
contents.description: Where personal data relating to a data subject are collected from the data subject, the controller shall, at the time when personal data are obtained, provide the data subject with all of the following information
contents.content: Identity and the contact details of the controller;Contact details of the data protection officer;Purposes of the processing;Legitimate interests pursued by the controller;Recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data;Intensions to transfer personal data to a third country;The period for which the personal data will be stored;Existence of the right to request from the controller access to personal data;Existence of the right to rectification;Existence of the right to erasure;Existence of the right to restriction of processing;Existence of the right to object to processing;Existence of the right to data portability;Existence of the right to withdraw consent;Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority;Whether the provision of personal data is a statutory or contractual requirement;The existence of automated decision-making

contents.title: Art14
contents.description: Where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject, the controller shall provide the data subject with the following information
contents.content: hallo a be c ;tritra trallala;bla bla blubb

contents.title: Art15
contents.description: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning him or her are being processed, and, where that is the case, access to the personal data and the following information
contents.shortTitle: Right of access by the data subject
contents.content: Right of access by the data subject

contents.title: Art16
contents.description: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller without undue delay the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning him or her. 2Taking into account the purposes of the processing, the data subject shall have the right to have incomplete personal data completed, including by means of providing a supplementary statement.

contents.title: Art17
contents.description: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay and the controller shall have the obligation to erase personal data without undue delay where one of the following grounds applies

contents.title: Art18
contents.description: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller restriction of processing where one of the following applies

contents.title: Art19
contents.description: The controller shall communicate any rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing carried out in accordance with Article 16, Article 17(1) and Article 18 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless this proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort. 2The controller shall inform the data subject about those recipients if the data subject requests it.

contents.title: Art20
contents.description: The data subject shall have the right to receive the personal data concerning him or her, which he or she has provided to a controller, in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have the right to transmit those data to another controller without hindrance from the controller to which the personal data have been provided, where.

contents.title: Art21
contents.description: The data subject shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to his or her particular situation, at any time to processing of personal data concerning him or her which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including profiling based on those provisions. 2The controller shall no longer process the personal data unless the controller demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the data subject or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims.

contents.title: Privacy Shootout
contents.description: Visualize the impact of a selection on data processing.

children.value: Data protection shoot-out

In modern online services, and particularly in digital ecosystems, users often have the opportunity to choose between different providers for a specific service or product. For example, different payment methods or shipping options are typically offered.

By selecting a service provider, users also decide on the details of the data processing performed. Depending on the choice, the recipients of the data change, and in some cases, the processed data categories may also change. Currently, users cannot recognize the data privacy implications of their selection. Especially in cases where processing is carried out on a contractual basis or based on legitimate interests, users could effectively influence the use of their data by selecting service providers within the online service.

When users are given the opportunity to choose between different service during the normal use of an online service, they should be provided with information about the data processing resulting from their selection. Based on this information, users should be enabled to consider their data privacy needs and preferences when making their selection.

When users can choose between different service providers, they can access an overview that visualizes the differences in the data processing performed. This overview uses the recipients of the data and the processed data categories as comparison measures. The comparison view allows users to intuitively identify the most data privacy-friendly choice, for example, by visualizing the number of processed data or the number of recipients.
This example integrates the additional information into an order process of an e-commerce platform. There are several shipping options to choose from.

contents.title: Data Table
contents.description: Add comprehensive privacy information to profile views.

children.value: Data Table

Data subjects have the right to obtain information about which of their data is processed when using a service. They should receive not only information about the processed data categories but also about the purposes of processing and the recipients involved.

In online services, users can often view the data they have provided in a profile. However, the data displayed here often only includes explicitly provided information by users and does not always consider all the data actually processed (e.g., usage data). Additionally, users usually do not receive any information in their profile about how the displayed profile data is processed.
In the profile view of an online service, all data processed during usage is displayed. Furthermore, users can view the purposes of use and possible recipients for each data category.

To inform themselves about the processing of their data, users navigate to the profile view of the online service. There, they receive an overview of all data categories processed during service usage, if possible, with specific data values. The presentation of data categories and values follows established formats (e.g., categorized lists). By selecting a data category, information about the purposes of use and the recipients of the data category is provided.
In this example, by clicking on a data category in the profile view, users can obtain information about which recipients process the respective data and for what purpose.

contents.title: In Place Transparency
contents.description: Provide data subjects with contextualized information when performing primary actions.

children.value: In Place Transparency

When using an online service, the actual data processing often depends on the functions used or the options chosen when using a service. For example, the choice of a payment service provider or a shipping method can determine the recipients of data in the context of an order on an e-commerce platform.

Currently provided information about data processing in the use of an online service often takes into account all possible processing, often by only mentioning general categories of data and recipients. For users, it is therefore almost impossible to get a clear picture of the actual data processing carried out in the context of a specific action.

Users should have the opportunity to receive transparency information about the data processing triggered by each action. The provided information should be as specific as possible and, for example, include specific recipients and data categories based on the selection options chosen by users.

When an action triggers data processing, users are visually alerted to this fact. Furthermore, they receive an overview of the specific data processing carried out for this action. This includes information about the processed data categories, recipients, and the purposes of processing. The information is provided to users without them needing to leave the context of the primary action. It is not necessary for users to, for example, switch to another page of the platform.

This example demonstrates the privacy interaction concept Inplace Transparency in the context of an online store. Before the order is executed and data is processed, users can call up further information on the data processings via the icon on the button.

contents.title: In Place Widthdraw
contents.description: Allow data subjects to withdraw a consent just befor the processing is about to take place.

children.value: In Place Withdraw
When data processing is based on consent, individuals have the right to withdraw their consent at any time, thereby preventing future processing of their data.

The management of consent is often offered in central locations for privacy or data protection settings in online services. If users want to prevent previously consented processing, they must first navigate to the relevant view. However, during the use of an online service, users often lose track of which data processing they could prevent by withdrawing consent.

When an action triggers data processing based on consent, users should be informed about it. They should also have the option to withdraw consent before triggering the data processing, without having to switch to a separate privacy settings area.

When an action triggers data processing based on consent, users are visually alerted to this fact. Furthermore, they receive detailed information about the specific data processing involved. This includes information about the processed data categories, recipients, and the purposes of processing. Users also have the option to withdraw consent for the specific data processing before they perform the primary action. The information and settings are provided to users without them needing to leave the context of the primary action.

The example shown integrates the in place withdraw into the ordering process of an online store. Before data is processed in association with an order, users can click on an icon next to the order button to call up a pop-up window with the required information and setting options.

contents.title: Informed Consent
contents.description: Gain informed consent without requiring data subjects to read privacy policies.

children.value: Informed Consent

When individuals make decisions about the processing of their data based on consent, they must be provided with comprehensive information about the processing being carried out. This includes details such as what data is being processed, the purpose of the data processing, and the other parties involved in the processing.

The necessary information is often provided to users in textual form. This creates an increased cognitive load in obtaining information about the purpose and manner of processing. This can lead users to either refuse consent even though they could benefit from the processing of their data or grant consent even though the processing does not align with their data privacy preferences.

When users are asked to provide consent for data processing, all the necessary information for an informed decision should be immediately available to them. The information should be presented in a way that users can easily align it with their data privacy preferences without a significant cognitive burden.

Information about the data processing in question is structured with a focus on the purpose, processed data categories, and involved recipients. This information is made available to users immediately. Users do not need to access additional resources to obtain this information.
Coming soon.

contents.title: Privacy Indicator
contents.description: Visualize the impact of entering data to a form.

children.value: Privacy Indicator

Users often have the opportunity to provide a variety of personal data in online services. This includes, for example, providing their personal address for shipping purposes on e-commerce platforms or sharing personal interests within the context of social media services.
When filling out forms, users usually receive no information about the purposes for which the provided data will be used or to whom the information will be disclosed after submission.

When users provide personal data, they should immediately receive information about how that data will be used within the context of the online service. This will empower users with the knowledge they need to decide whether to provide their data for the specific purpose or not.

Each form field where personal data could be entered receives a visual indicator that signals how many purposes the corresponding data will be used for after submission. Additionally, the number of potential recipients is provided. If needed, users are given detailed information about the data processing, including the specific purpose, associated recipients, and any other data processed for that particular purpose.
This example illustrates the privacy indicators on a form that is to be filled out when creating an account at an online store.

contents.title: Data Information
contents.description_text: The short description of a pattern to gain implicit consent.

children.value: Explicit Data Information
Current transparency measures often use categories of data or recipients.
Provide users with explicit data or recipients depending on the context.

contents.title: Data Subject Rights
contents.description_text: The short description of a pattern to gain implicit consent.

children.value: Data Information

contents.title: Explicit Consent
contents.description_text: The short description of a pattern to gain explicit consent.

children.value: Explicit Consent

Data processors sometimes need to obtain explicit consent from data-subjects to process data for a given purpose. They are required to provide extensive information about the processing to allow data-subjects to perform an informed decision.
In detail, data-subjects need to be provided with:
the identity and the contact details of the controller and, where applicable, of the controllerâ€™s representative
the contact details of the data protection officer, where applicable
the purposes of the processing for which the personal data are intended as well as the legal basis for the processing;
where the processing is based on point (f) of Article 6(1), the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party;
the recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, if any;
where applicable, the fact that the controller intends to transfer personal data to a third country or international organization
the period for which the personal data will be stored, or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period;
the existence of the right to request
the existence of the right to rectification
the existence of the right of erasure
the existence of the right of restriction of processing
the existence of the right to object to processing
the existence of the right to data portability;
where the processing is based on point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (a) of Article 9(2), the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time,
the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority;

whether the provision of personal data is a statutory or contractual requirement, or a requirement necessary to enter into a contract, as well as whether the data subject is obliged to provide the personal data and of the possible consequences of failure to provide such data;

the existence of automated decision-making, including profiling, referred to in Article 22(1) and (4) and, at least in those cases, meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject.

Current implementations of explicit consent forms do provide the required information about the data processing in an abstract and mostly textual form. Furthermore, data-subjects are required to explicit navigate to an additional resource in order to gain the information.

Users should be provided with all required information, visualized in an easy to access manner. User should not be required to leave the current task-context in order to retrieve the necessary information. The presentation of information should thereby meet usersâ€™ requirements by focusing on respecting information.
Data-subjects are enabled to perform informed decisions and thus are aware of the data processing.
